awd_titl_txt: Comparative Regional Inequality Dynamics: Multiscalar and Multinational Perspectives
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will comparatively analyze the dynamics of regional inequality in the United States and China using recent developments in geographic information science.  Because the investigators will focus on core-periphery structure, place mobility, and scalar effects, this project will significantly improve basic understanding of spatial inequality.  This project will advance knowledge about the dynamics of regional income inequality in a number of different ways.  It will provide a systematic study of the multi-scalar nature of regional inequality, thereby providing a clearer picture of the dynamics of regional inequality and its relationship to scale.  It will provide new insights about place mobility and about the core-periphery structure in regional development, and it will provide new perspectives regarding the role of geography in regional inequality.  Project findings should prove valuable to domestic and international organizations, such as non-profit organizations and the U.S. and Chinese governments, giving them improved understanding of inequality and facilitating the development of more informed policies that address development issues in equitable ways.

Questions about spatial inequality lie at the heart of the discipline of geography and are of major concern to governments.  While the geography of inequality has received new attention from academics and policy makers because of the recent global financial crisis, existing knowledge about spatial inequality dynamics is fragmented.  Furthermore, few comparative analyses have sought to synthesize the current state of knowledge.  The investigators will analyze regional inequality across states/provinces, metropolitan areas, and counties using conventional and spatial approaches.  They will decompose overall inequality into interregional and intraregional components.  They will examine regional income mobility using spatial Markov chain, spatiotemporal models, and decomposition techniques, which will focus on changing core-peripheral structure and mobility of places up and down the regional income distribution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Introduction

The National Science Foundation (NSF) awarded grant #1759746 to support the project titled "Comparative Analysis of Regional Inequality in the United States and China using Geographic Information Science." This project aimed to enhance our understanding of spatial inequality dynamics within the context of regional development, with a specific focus on core-periphery structures, place mobility, and scalar effects. Over the duration of this research initiative, significant progress has been made in advancing knowledge about regional income inequality, offering valuable insights for domestic and international organizations, policymakers, and academics.

 

Project Objectives

The primary objectives of this project were:

  • To systematically study the multi-scalar nature of regional inequality.
  • To gain insights into place mobility and core-periphery structures in regional development.
  •  To explore the role of geography in regional inequality dynamics.

Key Outcomes and Contributions

1. Multi-scalare Nature of Regional Inequality

The project has made substantial strides in uncovering the intricate multi-scalar nature of regional inequality in both the United States, China, and Mexico (see Figure 1). By comparing data across states/provinces, metropolitan areas, and counties, researchers have gained a comprehensive understanding of how inequality manifests at various spatial scales. This knowledge has provided a clearer picture of the complex dynamics of regional inequality and its relationship to different scales of geographic organization.

 

2. Insights into Place Mobility and Core-Periphery Structures

Through innovative methodologies such as spatial Markov chain analysis, spatiotemporal models, and decomposition techniques, this project has shed new light on place mobility and core-periphery structures within regions (see Figure 2). The findings have revealed the changing dynamics of core-peripheral regions and the mobility of places within the regional income distribution. This understanding is crucial for policymakers and organizations seeking to address regional disparities effectively.

 

3. Role of Geography in Regional Development

One of the significant contributions of this research has been its exploration of the role of geography in shaping regional inequality. By employing geographic information science and spatial analysis, the project has highlighted how geographical factors influence income disparities within and between regions (See figure 3). This perspective offers new avenues for addressing regional inequality from a geographic standpoint, enabling more informed and location-specific policy interventions.

 

Policy and Practical Implications

The outcomes of this research project have significant implications for both domestic and international organizations, as well as the governments of the United States and China:


1. Informed Policy Development: The project's findings provide valuable insights for policymakers, enabling them to design more targeted and effective policies to address regional inequality. By understanding the multi-scalar nature of inequality and the dynamics of core-periphery structures, governments can develop region-specific interventions.


2. Equitable Development: Non-profit organizations and governmental bodies can utilize the knowledge gained from this research to foster more equitable regional development strategies. This includes initiatives aimed at reducing income disparities and promoting inclusive growth.

3. International Collaboration: The comparative analysis of regional inequality between the United States and China has the potential to foster international collaboration and knowledge exchange. Lessons learned from each country's experiences can inform global efforts to tackle spatial inequality challenges.


Dissemination of Results
The project's findings have been disseminated through a range of academic publications, conferences, and policy briefings. Research outputs have been shared with relevant stakeholders, ensuring that the knowledge generated reaches the widest possible audience. In addition, datasets and tools developed during the project have been made available for public use, promoting further research in this critical area.


Conclusion
The NSF-funded project, "Comparative Analysis of Regional Inequality in the United States and China using Geographic Information Science," has made significant strides in advancing our understanding of regional inequality dynamics. By systematically studying the multi-scalar nature of regional inequality, gaining insights into place mobility and core-periphery structures, and exploring the role of geography, this research has provided valuable contributions to the field of geography and regional development. Moreover, its practical implications for policymakers and organizations working to address regional disparities underscore the project's societal relevance. The project's outcomes will continue to inform and inspire efforts to promote more equitable regional development in the United States, China, and beyond.
